Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 23: Proceeding to Bodhgaya.
Continuing to pursue the end he had in view, the Bodhisattva seated himself at first in a cave – the margins of which were flecked with flowers and fruits.
Inscription - English: Seated on a rock mountain, the mountain collapsed
Manual - English: The Buddha leaves the rocky hill after a sliding of rocks. Nāga King, Kālika (dus can) praises the Buddha. A grass-seller named Svastika (bkra shis) and his servants offer grass to the Buddha. The Buddha leaves for Bodhgaya (byang chub snying po).

Sun of Faith - English: The mountain [where the cave was located] crumbled beneath him.
The gods explained: “You have accumulated so much merit that no place on earth can support your weight except the Vajrāsana (Rdo rje’i gdan), which is to be found not far from here.”
The gods accompanied him, clearing for him the path ahead. Wherever the Bodhisattva’s foot fell, lotus-flowers emerged from the ground,
and the waters of the four oceans ran into the prints of his feet – transforming them into bowls for the lotuses to float in.
The Bodhisattva continued to walk and each time his foot touched the ground, the earth rang clear as a bronze bell.
Clouds of thrushes swirled around him, and a multitude of wild animals skipped playfully behind.
The gods sprinkled him with iridescent raindrops and fanned him with a soft and fragrant breeze.
In the bed of the river Nairañjana there lived Kālika (Dus can) a serpent-king who was blind, but who recovered his sight each time a Buddha appeared in the world.
Thus, Kālika had gazed upon the face of Krakucchaṇḍa-buddha (sangs rgyas ’Khor ba ’jig) as well as upon the faces of other buddhas of past times. [Hence] that day [too], he could see.
When he heard the earth ringing like a bell, he left his underwater palace and made for the surface of the earth.
Although he perceived the Bhagavan from a long way off, he knew, without the smallest doubt, that this man would become a buddha.
He said [to the Bodhisattva]: Those whom I saw in the past, all became powerful buddhas. The fact that I can see you, O Wise One, shows that you’re no different from them,
he said as a preamble to a long paean of praise.
A little farther along, the Bodhisattva met Svastika (Bkra shis) a young hay merchant that the king of the gods had placed [on purpose] in the former’s way.
The boy was carrying an armful of sweet fragrant grasses gathered from Gandhamādana (ri spos ngad ldan).
In response to the Bodhisattva’s request, Svastika joyously and with reverence, offered the sheaf of stalks to him.
Inscription - English: Receives kuśa grass from the grass seller Svastika

Sun of Faith - English: The Bodhisattva walked on till Bodhgaya and climbed the steps to the Vajrasāna.
Scene working notes: From here down, this could be an additional scene, with the figure of the Buddha seated on grass matt at Vajrasana.

Sun of Faith - English: There, at the foot of a fig-tree – which would henceforth be known as the Tree of Enlightenment – he prepared his throne.
The kuśa grass-stalks, flung down in a heap to serve as a cushion, distributed themselves evenly, forming a clockwise arrangement.
By this, the Bodhisattva knew without the shadow of a doubt that the following day he would attain the highest wisdom.
He seated himself in the vajra position, straightened his back, and keeping his mind in the clear light state,
made this vow: “So long as I have not attained perfect enlightenment, I will not rise from this adamantine position!”
